data.title: the code of a.c was replaced by b.h

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.8.1 (ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281, 2016-12-19T14:49:23.350Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|GBKtoUTF8|bukas|0.0.2|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.9.3|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.6.2|
|Material-theme|zhuangtongfa|1.0.3|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. u have a.c and b.h files, a.c include b.h
2. open a.c
3. in a.c ctrl + leftClick open the b.h
4. close b.h
5. ctrl + move cursor on the code < #include ”b.h“ > in a.c , the code of a.c will be replaced by the code of b.h

data.title: When name of thread is changed, the UI is not updated.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Report name of a thread as `Thread 1`
2. Change name of the thread as `main()`

Expected: Threads name to change in UI
Actual: Name in Call Stack window still is `Thread 1`

When we report a ThreadCreated event, we receive a ThreadsRequest which we respond to with the id and Name of threads. When code then hits a breakpoint we are able to actually resolve the thread name to something besides `Thread 1` so with the same thread id we change the name but the UI doesn't reflect this. 

Also: Is there a reason why after every ThreadCreated event, that we are queried for Threads?

data.title: window.restoreFullscreen has unintended side effect of forcing openFilesInNewWindow=false behavior
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.8.1 (ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281, 2016-12-19T14:49:23.350Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.1.4|
|Go|lukehoban|0.6.52|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.6.2|
|PowerShell|ms-vscode|0.8.0|
|incremental-search|siegebell|0.2.1|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open some file in VS Code and maximize the VS Code window
2. set window.restoreFullscreen to true in user settings (window.openFilesInNewWindow is not set and the default value/behavior should be "true")
3. Open another file by running "code file-name" from command line

Expected: file should open in a new, maximized window
Actual: file opens in existing VS Code window

data.title: C++ syntax highlighting is broken
Ruby word match includes ":"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1

Given the following snippet:

```
Foo::Bar.baz(:fnord)
```

* Position caret on `Bar` and hit Cmd-D. This will highlight `:Bar` instead of just `Bar`.
* Postion caret on `fnord` and hit Cmd-D. This will hightlight `:fnord` instead of `fnord`.

Both are surprising and wrong. A symbol is _not_ a word. The `:` is not part of it, in the same way that quotes are not part of `"a string"`.

data.title: Multiselect via ctrl+d case insensitivity makes it useless

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.8.1 (ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281, 2016-12-19T14:41:20.664Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.38-1-MANJARO
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|Go|lukehoban|0.6.51|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

consider this block of code:
```
	accountQryConn   *grpc.ClientConn
	accountQryClient proto.AccountQueryClient
```

when I select 'account' and hit alt+d a few times it will select it like this.

![2017-01-06-150041_626x115_scrot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1015732/21731141/eb1079a8-d420-11e6-89a9-280b0f8d463b.png)

this is fine, but when I do this, I am doing it to replace it with something else. So I'll start typing:

![2017-01-06-150136_731x106_scrot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1015732/21731163/09140b68-d421-11e6-913e-a0bf92e9ed67.png)

but now my case is broken for my second string.

This is fine in a small example, but very annoying. 

Currently the case matches whatever is highlighted in the search widget. Behold what happens if I turn off case sensitivity: 

![2017-01-06-150329_1605x153_scrot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1015732/21731213/4eb44f16-d421-11e6-8fba-8f90ed207420.png)

This is incredibly annoying. I can't think of a time when you would want to multiselect case-insensitively with ctrl+d. It simply selects the wrong stuff, because in code it's always case sensitive. So depending on whatever I did last with ctrl+f, my ctrl+d either works or is annoying.

I think ctrl+d should always be case sensitive, or have a button that's not search-tied that does a case sensitive string selection match across the file

My two cents.

data.title: Can code.cmd have higher precedence on the PATH than code (the shell script)?

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
See discussion for more context: https://twitter.com/Nick_Craver/status/817190115491647489

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open windows explorer to some directory
2. Focus address bar and type "code ."
3. This will run "code ." with the current working directory set to explorer's current folder

However this results in an application picker since `code.sh` has its extension removed during packaging so it's simply `code`, so it takes precedence over `code.cmd` and Windows doesn't know how to open code(.sh) the shell script. `code.cmd .` works fine, so right now it's possible to do this, just much less discoverable `code.cmd .`

If the shell script is removed from the PATH then `code .` works fine as the command resolves to `code.cmd`.

data.title: Intellisense can't be overridden by JSDoc in normal Javascript
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1 vommit ee428b
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a function that returns something that TS thinks it can figure out a signature for
2. Add jsdoc with `@returns`
2. Use the function elsewhere

TSServer does a great job with signatures when using plain javascript - sometimes. But often I want to just use JSDoc to explicitly provide a signature, because it's indetermine or TS can't figure it out correctly. 

e.g.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/573056/21724642/44ec677a-d403-11e6-9b3c-0cd42b5143b9.png)

Using this function:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/573056/21724394/2556b894-d402-11e6-8da2-b1c0158b8215.png)

I would expect to see the signature I defined in `@returns`.  ("bind" actually seems to have another issue too -- I would think it knows to return the same sig of what you invoked "bind" on, but that's a different story, in this case I just want it to use my explicitly described signature).

This seems to happen if Typescript *thinks* it knows the signature of what I'm returning. It doesn't happen if I return something it truly doesn't know about - e.g. a property of an object that's not defined yet; in that case it always uses my JSDoc.

I would think that JSDoc should *always* supercede what TS Server thinks the signature is, if present.

data.title: More configurable builds for C/C++
data.body:
Feature Request

Using cpptool you can define configurations. Those configurations can only be used just for include paths and symbols databases. It would be nice to use those configurations in build to specify compilation flags (e.g. debug/release build). I would like to be able to change those configurations and build accordingly to specified configuration. In other words i want to be able to add compilation arguments for specific configuration only.  Now its only possible to change your build by modifying tasks.json file, which is not a big deal but still.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. select a few lines (press alt and use the mouse, or use alt+shift+up/down, or multiselect using search)
2. press ctrl + x to cut the lines
3. press ctrl + v to paste the lines
4. the lines don't paste
5. go to a new line and paste
6. the lines still don't paste

data.title: Support Bash for Windows as a first class citizen
data.body:
If VS code properly supported bash on windows it will make windows a viable machine to actually buy as a developer.   

By proper support I mean that extensions (like the golang extension for example) shell out to bash not to windows terminal.  Environment variables are respected from bash. Debugging works via bash, git works via bash, etc. Basically nothing goes through the windows terminal at all and every command is done via bash.  

This would likely make me buy a windows machine.

data.title: Check for places to use fast URI serialisation (like HistoryService)
data.body:
![screen shot 2017-01-06 at 10 32 30](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1794099/21713823/1c868380-d3fc-11e6-8b48-4ab192a42694.png)



When profiling the `"[renderer] restore editor view state"` you will notice that ~10ms are spend in the history service comparing the current input with old input. The time is spend in `handleEditorEventInHistory` which is busy retrieving data from storage, building URIs and comparing them against other URIs. The code uses `URI.parse` and `URI.toString` which have many safe guards and checks and are consequently not super-fast. However, when you can trust URI, like in this case as they are generated/stored/retrieved from use you should use `URI.toJSON` and `URI.revive` or better and easier [`marshalling#stringify/parse`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/base/common/marshalling.ts#L9) which are drop in replacements (and used by workers/ext-host communication)
